rComments: The syllabus  did not specify what material should be read for each lecture, and the readings themselves consisted of a single book written by the Shorter himself. Lectures consisted of powerpoint slides and the expectation that history students should already have a background in medicine and anatomy. Overall, interesting subject, poor execution.

Shorter is a highly approachable, engaging, and understanding professor. While the course had a textbook, it was seldom used.  However, if you did read it, it may help you in weekly class discussions. Spend time understanding assignment expectations, as confusion is to be expected.  I would recommend  talking to him during his office hours.
Brilliant, charming, helpful, and interesting.  Professor Shorter is one of U of Tâ€™s many intellectual trinkets.

Likes to hear himself talk. Syllabus was a joke as the only reading was a single book written by none other than himself, and no weekly topics. Class was more like a meandering question and answer period with himself as the fount of knowledge. Fortunately, he was saved by an extremely engaging subject--social history of medicine.
One of the best lecturers I had had.  He's funny, engaging and makes a potentially boring topic like history a lot of fun.  Definitely take this class if you have the chance!!

Prof Shorter was one of the best profs I've had at UofT. He was a very engaging speaker, and his slides were most helpful. You could tell he really loved the subject, and was extremely knowledgable. I would reccomend anyone take a class taught by this man.
